subject: Add debug option to verify iptables rules
commit_message:
Add debug option to verify iptables rules

The iptables apply logic performs diffs between the rules in the
system and the desired rule state. If the format generated in
Neutron does not match the format of iptables-save, Neutron will
generate unnecessary deletions and adds for rules that it thinks
are different when they are actually the same.

A simple way to detect mismatches is to run the _apply function
twice each time and generate an error if the second one results
in changes since that implies that the rules the first one applied
did not match the format of iptables-save. However, this comes at
a performance cost and doesn't offer benefits to operators.

This patch adds a config option to debug_iptables_rules that
is set to False by default. When set to True it will perform
the secondary check described above.

This enables it for all of the jobs that call the gate_hook.sh
script.

This is only meant to assist catching development errors of
iptables, it SHOULD NOT be turned on by operators.

subject: Enable DeprecationWarning in test environments
commit_message:
Enable DeprecationWarning in test environments

Neutron is refactoring a lot of its code. For example, common entities
are being moved to neutron-lib. When code is refactored it is marked
with debtcollector, which issues a deprecation warning. In the next
release the old entity will be removed. Consuming projects (like
tricircle) must update to comply with the new entity before the old
one is removed.

Tricircle maintainers must monitor deprecation warnings and act on them
before the next release.

Many deprecations are triggered early (on imports, for example)
before the warnings are enabled by the WarningsFixture in the
base test class.

To make sure all DeprecationWarning messages are emitted we enable
them via the PYTHONWARNINGS environment variable.

subject: All Cinder LVM operations run with LVM_SYSTEM_DIR
commit_message:
All Cinder LVM operations run with LVM_SYSTEM_DIR

Up to now only a subset of LVM commands (pvs, vgs, lvs & lvdisplay)
ran with an appropriate LVM_SYSTEM_DIR value set in their environment,
based upon the lvm_conf_file config option.

As a result this meant that the /etc/lvm/lvm.conf file still had to
permit scanning of the devices providing the LVM PVs backing Cinder's
Volume Groups. Which of course means that the host and Cinder LVM
operations were not truly isolated from each other.

This has now been rectified by ensuring that all LVM commands are run
with an appropriate LVM_SYSTEM_DIR environment setting.

All LVM commands are constructed as a cmd list prior to being passed
to the _lvm() method or lvm_cmd() staticmethod.

Updated the etc/cinder/rootwrap.d/volume.filters entries for all the
LVM commands to reflect this; they now use the EnvFilter rather than
CommandFilter. Removed redundant _lvmconf filter entries.

Affected unit tests, such as those for Brick LVM, have been updated
to work with this new model.

Notes with regard to Upgrades:
==============================
There shouldn't be any impact on upgrade as a result of this patch
unless a pre-existing effort has been made to fully isolate the host
LVM environment from the Cinder LVM environment by having the host
/etc/lvm/lvm.conf file ignore the devices that will be backing the
Cinder LVM VGs.

However, given that this patch is intended to fix the issues that
prevented the deployment of a system with true isolation of the
host and Cinder LVM environments, I don't believe there is likely
to be any upgrade impact.

If no lvm_conf_file is specified in cinder.conf then before and
after this change any Cinder LVM commands will have been using the
system default lvm.conf file.

If an lvm_conf_file was previously specified, and it used filtering
to limit the set of devices scanned to only those devices that
Cinder should be targeting, then the effect would have been limited
to the show/display commands, whereas now all Cinder generated
LVM commands will be affected. This shouldn't cause problems since
Cinder LVM commands shouldn't be trying to access other devices on
the system anyway.

Change-Id: I9420c3d8b232367b610622d94e8923dedcc314e6
Closes-Bug: #1506220
UpgradeImpact

subject: Allow triggering cleanup from API
commit_message:
Allow triggering cleanup from API

Now that we support having multiple c-vol nodes serving the same storage
backend under one "host", they no longer clean all resources from that
host on start, only those from their own node.  So we need a way to
trigger the cleanup of the resources that were being processed by a
failed node.

This patch adds a new API endpoint (/workers/cleanup) that will trigger
cleanup for c-vol nodes as microversion 3.3.

The cleanup will be performed by other nodes that share the same host,
so at least one of them must be up to be able to do the cleanup.

Cleanup cannot be triggered during a cloud upgrade, but a restarted node
will still cleanup it's own resources during an upgrade.

If no arguments are provided cleanup will issue a clean message for all
nodes that are down, but we can restrict which nodes we want to be
cleaned using parameters `service_id`, `host`, `binary`, `node_id`,
`disabled`, `name`.

Cleaning specific resources is also possible using `resource_type` and
`resource_id` parameters.

We can even force cleanup on nodes that are up with `is_up`, but that's
not recommended.

API will return a dictionary with 2 lists, one with nodes that have been
issued a cleanup request (`cleaning`) and another list with nodes that
cannot be cleaned right now because there is no alternative node to do
the cleanup in that host (`unavailable`).

Data returned for each node in the lists is the same as the summary list
of nodes: `id`, `name` and `state`.

Specs: https://review.openstack.org/236977
Patch in series: 5/7

APIImpact: New /workers/cleanup entry
Implements: blueprint cinder-volume-active-active-support

subject: Make c-bak use workers table for cleanup
commit_message:
Make c-bak use workers table for cleanup

To be able to support multiple nodes working with the same resources we
have added the workers table to keep track of which node is working with
each specific resource.

This patch makes c-bak service work with this new table by adding
entries on cleanable operations and removing them once these operations
have completed.

Service cleanup on initialization has also been changed to use this new
table so nodes will cleanup only resources from operations they left on
the air and leave any operations that are being processed by other nodes.

Backup nodes have been traditionally tightly coupled to volume nodes,
and though we now have the possibility to scale out backups
independently of volumes we may still force backups only to work if the
backup and volume services are on the same node.

And it's for this case, where we have them in the same node as we used
to, that we need c-bak to also support the workers mechanism, because we
can deploy c-vol in HA A-A fashion together with c-bak.

When working in Active-Active configurations nodes may go down, and we
may want those nodes to be automatically cleaned.

This patch adds this functionality to do auto cleanup on nodes that go

heartbeat of the node.

The number of seconds is defined as a multiple of `service_down_time`
with `auto_cleanup_checks` configuration option.

there is no other node in the host that can do the cleaning
(`unavailable` key).

of nodes: `id`, `name` and `state`.

subject: Ignore: personal repo and branch test
commit_message:
Ignore: personal repo and branch test

Networking-OVN use manager_option configuation for NB and SB

NB and SB dbs are handled by separate ovsdb-server processes. The
ovsdb-server proess manage dbs based on the schemas for OVN NorthBound
and SouthBound. These schemas do not have any Manager Options similar
to the Open_vSwitch schema. As a result, for e.g., the frequency of
inactivity probes sent to clients from the ovsdb-server cannot be
modified.

This patch addresses the above problem by creating independent
 "conf.db"s for NB and SB. The ovsdb-server process which handles
the NB will handle a NB_conf.db as well, ditto for the ovsdb-server
that handles the SB.

Similar result can be obtained by adding a Manager Table to the
NorthBound and SouthBound DBs as well. In such case there would
not be a need for a separate "config" database. I'm willing to
consider this solution as well pending feedback.

Sample Calls for modifying the inactivity probe timeout value:

ovs-appctl -t /usr/local/var/run/openvswitch/ovnnb_db.ctl vlog/set any:any:dbg
ovs-appctl -t /usr/local/var/run/openvswitch/ovnnb_db.ctl ovsdb-server/list-remotes

manager_ip=`ovs-appctl -t /usr/local/var/run/openvswitch/ovnnb_db.ctl ovsdb-server/list-remotes | grep ptcp | awk -F\: '{print $3}'`
manager_port=`ovs-appctl -t /usr/local/var/run/openvswitch/ovnnb_db.ctl ovsdb-server/list-remotes | grep ptcp | awk -F\: '{print $2}'`

ovs-vsctl --db=unix:/usr/local/var/run/openvswitch/ovnnb_db.sock --no-wait set-manager ptcp:$manager_port:$manager_ip
ovs-vsctl --db=unix:/usr/local/var/run/openvswitch/ovnnb_db.sock list Manager
manager_uuid=`ovs-vsctl --db=unix:/usr/local/var/run/openvswitch/ovnnb_db.sock list Manager | grep _uuid | awk -F\: '{print $2}'`
manager_uuid=${manager_uuid//[[:blank:]]/}
ovs-vsctl --db=unix:/usr/local/var/run/openvswitch/ovnnb_db.sock --no-wait set Manager $manager_uuid inactivity_probe=0
ovs-vsctl --db=unix:/usr/local/var/run/openvswitch/ovnnb_db.sock list Manager

ovs-vsctl --db=unix:/usr/local/var/run/openvswitch/ovnnb_db.sock --no-wait set Manager $manager_uuid inactivity_probe=5

Change-Id: Iecfd9bb78ee40438d2307a39aac5f2e0c9682817
Signed-off-by: Amitabha Biswas <abiswas@us.ibm.com>

subject: Update metadata proxy when router interface add/remove
commit_message:
Update metadata proxy when router interface add/remove

If enable isolated metadata for network, a metadata proxy will be
spawned for network with isolated subnets. After the network becomes
non-isolated, metadata proxy from router will provide connection to
metadata service, and metadata proxy for network will be useless.

The process will do no harm, but will have a load issue in large scale
env. Because every network is born to be isolated, every network will
have its own metadata proxy. After lots of networks connecting to
router, there might be many useless metadata proxy from networks, which
will cost the load of host.

This patch will spawn/kill network metadata proxy process, when router
interface create/udpate/delete. So the network metadata proxy will be
spawned/killed, when the network switch between isolated/non-isolated.

Closes-bug: #1557002

subject: A common flow classifier that can be used by Neutron features
commit_message:
A common flow classifier that can be used by Neutron features

 This patch documents the two approaches that can be
 considered to support the common flow classifier functionality.
 Multiple Neutron Stadium features need flow classifier functionality.
 Instead of each feature creating its own FC API, we should have one
 common FC API that can be used by all the features. Currently
 the features that need FC are: Tap as a service, SFC, QoS, FW, BGP/VPN.
 Common FC APIs should be a superset of FC rules used by existing features.
 The goal is to come up with one consistent way of defining the API and
 classification rules. Through this common FC API, each Neutron feature
 can define its own FC and then associate the FC instance with the feature itself.

 An approach will be chosen based on design comprehensiveness, usage simplicity,
 future extensions, implementation, upgrade, and performance complexities.

 More patches may follow up on design internals for the
 adopted implementation approach.

subject: Manually specify from_dict parameters
commit_message:
Manually specify from_dict parameters

The way from_dict is structured today means that it is virtually
impossible for a subclass to use it. The function looks only at its own
__init__ variables and then creates a class with them. If a subclass is
adding something to to_dict (they almost all do) then there is no way
for that subclass to add anything to the from_dict so that it is
correctly reconstructed.

This problem is solvable by the pattern of passing keyword args through
to the constructor and having from_dict add to these arguments if they
are not already present. This pattern is already used by from_environ.

This change also moves from an inspecting __init__ args to explicitly
specifying the arguments supported by from_dict. This will be required
to start doing debtcollector and parameter cleanup without breaking
compatibility in the subclasses where the values returned by inspect may
not be those we actually want to pass to __init__.

subject: Plug updated VIFs
commit_message:
Plug updated VIFs

A plug of a VIF does two operations.  It creates the client side
adapter.  But it also does a 'treat' of the VIF so that the neutron
agent is aware of it.

It is expected that when the nova compute boots up that all of the VIFs
get plugged.  Specifically so that they can be retreated.

As a performance optimization, the PowerVM driver did not run the
plug_vifs if we detected that the client network adapter was already
there.  However, this led to an issue.  The VIF wasn't being
re-'treated' on the nova compute boot.

This wasn't an issue, unless you had the I/O running through the VM that
the nova-compute was running on (like OVS or Linux Bridge).  If that
VM were to be rebooted, then the elements on the trunk adapter (like the
OVS UUID) are lost.  They do not persist via reboot.

This is the OpenStack design and specifically why OpenStack calls
plug_vifs on each compute node reboot.  This change brings the
nova-powervm driver in line with that behavior.

The biggest change is that the OVS will now set the UUID on the trunk
port and therefore the OVS neutron agent will finish its initialization.

Change-Id: I1fcd708a39f87282a77a8c8db75dcbbff83e4d4e
Closes-Bug: #1609497

Protection plugin now needs to implement the set_activities()

operation (protect, delete, restore).

Activity can be any callable. In case the activity returns a
generator, it is iterated until completion. The iteration interval
is defined in configuration. The last yielded value is taken as the
activity result.

Main activity is called after worker activities and dependent
resource's main activities are complete.

subject: Add REST API support for get me a network
commit_message:
Add REST API support for get me a network

This adds the 2.37 microversion to the REST API for automatically
allocating a network, i.e. get me a network.

The majority of the changes to the REST API concern request
validation. 'networks' is now required in the server POST body
after this microversion. The 'auto' or 'none' special network
uuid values are used, but if specified, can not be specified
with any other requested network values.

The other special case that is checked is when the minimum
compute service version is not new enough to support this change,
i.e. a Mitaka compute will not have the network API code that
knows how to deal with the special auto/none network IDs. Because
the REST API is checking the service version, the service caches
the service version after the first check. Once all computes are
updated to Newton then a restart of the nova-api service(s) will
be required to flush the cache. A release note is provided for
this situation.

The api-ref docs are also updated for this microversion including
an example API sample request.

The matching Tempest change to test this is here:

I89b18709e0cfbbcbf9be96a91a13a1356cdf85b0

The matching python-novaclient change is here:

I6636ddcd3be7bf393d2d69cc6c1ba5c7d65ff674

Implements blueprint get-me-a-network

subject: Fix help text of swift_store_config_file
commit_message:
Fix help text of swift_store_config_file

While attempting to improve help text for configuration option
"swift_store_config_file", None is incorrectly listed as a
possible value. None is incorrect because a configuration option
can either be set or not. It can't be set to None. When no value
is set for a configuration option, it is inherently parsed as None
by oslo.config. Hence, there is no need to specify None as a
possible value.

Also, the configuration option swift_store_config_file is marked as
secret. Although the file pointed by this path can contain
credentials, the path itself need not be marked secret. This in fact
may make debugging harder if the file path is not logged clearly.
